Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Predicting Memory: Pattern Classification of Anticipatory Brain States Associated with Memory Formation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to learn from experience is vital to successful human behavior. Critically though, our memories of past experiences are not veridical records of the events that transpired. Instead, what gets encoded and preserved is shaped by what matters to the individual; in other words, what is motivating. Previous research suggests that when individuals are anticipating the arrival of valuable information from their environments, key memory-related brain regions like the hippocampus increase their activity. By boosting activity in these regions it is assumed that memory encoding is facilitated, thus promoting successful recording of the upcoming information. The goals of this project were to further investigate this phenomenon in humans by applying techniques from the machine learning field in order to try and predict the brain states that will lead to successful memory formation. 

This work was carried out during the summer of 2010 in the Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory at Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School of Singapore, under the directorship of Dr. Michael Chee. Dr. Chee’s laboratory offered the unique opportunity to work first-hand with experts in the fields of functional magnetic resonance imaging and machine learning, specifically multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA).  MVPA is a novel analysis technique, one feature of which is to be able to generate predictions about a subject’s current cognitive state. I exploited this feature in an attempt to make predictions about whether or not a subject would remember an upcoming stimulus based on the activity levels in key brain regions in the moments before seeing the stimulus. The dataset was collected from human subjects participating in a rewarded memory task. 

In 7 of the 11 subjects tested, our algorithms were able to make above-chance predictions on whether trials would be subsequently remembered or forgotten. However, overall group accuracy was not significantly better than chance, indicating strong individual differences. Future work will focus on elucidating these differences. I will also continue to improve the prediction algorithms themselves in order to maximize the classification accuracy and generalizability to diverse subject populations.
